abstract.p: Rocco Landesman letter on Robert Brustein's play Nobody Dies on Friday, and Brustein's negative feelings about Lee Strasberg (Patricia Bosworth's April 19 report)

block.p: It is so disheartening to read in The New York Times Arts and Leisure section yet another article that belongs in People magazine. Patricia Bosworth's report [''Despise a Guy for 50 Years? Put Him in a Play,'' April 19] on Robert Brustein's play ''Nobody Dies on Friday'' glosses over the issues of Lee Strasberg's career that engaged Mr. Brustein, focusing instead on the gossip surrounding the production.

It is so disheartening to read in The New York Times Arts and Leisure section yet another article that belongs in People magazine. Patricia Bosworth's report [''Despise a Guy for 50 Years? Put Him in a Play,'' April 19] on Robert Brustein's play ''Nobody Dies on Friday'' glosses over the issues of Lee Strasberg's career that engaged Mr. Brustein, focusing instead on the gossip surrounding the production.
What I totally fail to understand is how Mr. Brustein is supposed to hate someone he never knew, or how he has a score to settle with someone who never attacked him.

Ms. Bosworth must assume that Times readers could not possibly be interested in the ideas in the play, only in the controversy around it: Mr. Brustein's resentment of Strasberg, and Strasberg's family's resentment of Mr. Brustein. It is exactly this preoccupation with personalities and celebrity -- and how it compromised Strasberg's work and life -- that is the real subject of the play.
The writer is the president of Jujamcyn Theaters.
